channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II: The One Constant in an Inconstant World
item.description: From fading empire to the Cold War to 1970s turmoil to Brexit to Covid, “she was always there.” What will Britain, and the world, do without her?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip amid memorial bouquets at Buckingham Palace in 1997, the year Princess Diana died.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96; Was Britain’s Longest-Reigning Monarch
item.description: She ruled for seven decades, unshakably committed to the rituals of her role amid epic social and economic change and family scandal.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in 2012.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II: A Life in Photos
item.description: Elizabeth took her first steps in a world we recognize only from sepia photographs, and became Britain’s longest-reigning monarch. Here are a selection of images from her life.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mona Boshnaq
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: U.S. Asks Judge in Trump Special Master Case to Lift Key Parts of Order
item.description: The Justice Department asked a judge to hold off on enacting key parts of her order, including a temporary ban on its ability to use files seized from former President Donald J. Trump in its inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department is barred for now from using a trove of documents seized in a search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago residence and club in Florida.

item.title: Trump’s Post-Election Fund-Raising Comes Under Scrutiny by Justice Dept.
item.description: A federal grand jury has issued subpoenas seeking information about Save America PAC, which was formed as Donald J. Trump promoted baseless assertions about election fraud.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The fact that federal prosecutors are seeking information about Save America PAC is a significant turn in a sprawling investigation into the roles that Donald J. Trump and his allies played in trying to overturn the 2020 election.

item.title: Fairview Fire Rages in Southern California, As Storm Threatens to Bring Floods
item.description: A storm threatens to bring heavy rain and strong winds to the state’s largest wildfire, creating a recipe for a compound disaster in Southern California.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: CalFire firefighters building a line to contain the Fairview Fire near Hemet, California, on Thursday.

item.title: As Crises Mount, Europe Turns Once Again to Big Spending
item.description: The standoff with Russia over Ukraine and rising energy prices are rapidly overturning European economic orthodoxy, with barely a peep of dissent.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, center, at a Siemens Energy plant in Muelheim an der Ruhr, last month.

item.title: How Do Japanese Show They Care? By Sending a Telegram.
item.description: Millions of the messages still crisscross Japan each year, offering congratulations or condolences in a way that more modern communications cannot.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A telegram and a preserved flower that Asuka and Hiroshi Kanno received for their wedding.

item.title: Oberlin Says It Will Pay $36.59 Million to a Local Bakery
item.description: Gibson’s Bakery said the liberal arts college had falsely accused it of racism after a Black student was caught shoplifting.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:description: Gibson's Bakery, which is across the street from Oberlin College in Ohio.

item.title: Bill de Blasio Knows New York Is Tired of Him. He’s at Peace With It.
item.description: On the eve of the former mayor’s return to his New England home, a frank exit interview about his time in New York.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: China’s Public Puts on a Show of Zero Covid for an Audience of One
item.description: Because of Xi Jinping’s unrelenting policy, the Chinese people put up with a precarious existence filled with lockdowns, quarantines and mass testing.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:description: A line to be tested for the coronavirus in Chongqing, China, last week.

item.title: China’s Zero-Covid Approach Explained as Chengdu Lockdown Is Extended
item.description: The country where the coronavirus first emerged is committed to going to great lengths to stop its spread.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing in Beijing last month. Others may debate whether China’s approach to controlling the virus goes too far, but its leaders are staying with it.

item.title: Filthy Plane Videos Ignite Debate About Airline Cleanliness
item.description: Recent social media posts suggest that the days of clean flights may be going the way of masks. And they’ve ignited a debate about who bears responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy

item.title: Daring to Speak Up About Race in a Divided School District
item.description: What happened when a superintendent in northern Michigan raised the issue of systemic racism?
item.dc:creator: Daniel Bergner
item.category: White Fragility: Why It's So Hard for White People to Talk about Racism (Book)
item.media:credit: Holly Andres for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephanie Long, the school superintendent of Leland, Mich., in August.

item.title: When In-Laws Share an Apartment, and Become Your Neighbors
item.description: In-laws typically have one of the most fraught family dynamics. What about two sets of in-laws living together down a hall from their children and grandchildren?
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Clark Hodgin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hannah Seligson fixed the hair of her daughter, Leah, 4, while her mother-in-law, Adele Geffen Eil, played with her son, Gabriel, 2.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Has Died. She Embodied the Myth of the Good Monarch.
item.description: Queen Elizabeth seemed to rise above the tawdry mess of politics.
item.dc:creator: Serge Schmemann
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Mourn the Queen, Not Her Empire
item.description: She helped obscure a bloody history of decolonization whose proportions and legacies have yet to be adequately acknowledged.
item.dc:creator: Maya Jasanoff
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Wartime Economics Comes to Europe
item.description: Sometimes rationing and price controls are unavoidable.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:description: In order to save energy in Germany, buildings and monuments lit for aesthetic purposes will no longer be illuminated at night.

item.title: You Can’t Talk About MAGA America in Hushed Tones
item.description: Trump is the chosen candidate of reactionary billionaires and fanatical opponents of racial and gender equality for a reason.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:description: Speaking truth to Trump.

item.title: China’s Heat Wave Was a Frightening Vision of Earth’s Future
item.description: On a trip through the epicenter, ravaged landscapes, paralyzed cities and populations pushed to extremes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Bossons
item.media:description: A dry riverbed last month along the Jialing River, a major tributary of the Yangtze River, in Chongqing, China.

item.title: The Exceptionally American Experience of Selling My Plasma
item.description: The world’s blood banks are filled with “donations” from America’s poor.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Veselka

item.title: American Turmoil, as Seen by a War Correspondent
item.description: Luke Mogelson watches the country go berserk in “The Storm Is Here.”
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: The Storm Is Here: An American Crucible (Book)
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scene at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: The Immortal Awfulness of Open Plan Workplaces
item.description: No amount of evidence can bury this bad idea.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks

item.title: An Era Ends
item.description: After 70 years, the reign of Queen Elizabeth II is over.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The queen on a visit to Germany in 2015.

item.title: How Queen Elizabeth II Saved the Monarchy
item.description: A look back at the life of Britain’s longest-reigning monarch, who led her country and the royal family through moments of enormous upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Rachelle Bonja, Stella Tan, Mooj Zadie, Jessica Cheung, Lynsea Garrison, Rachel Quester, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Mike Benoist, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth and her eldest son, Charles, at the State Opening of Parliament in 2019. He will now be known as King Charles III.

item.title: When There’s Nothing in the Fridge
item.description: Pasta, beans and more pantry cooking saves the day.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Gentl and Hyers for The New York Times

item.title: A Goodbye to Readers and a Reflection
item.description: In Shira Ovide’s last On Tech newsletter, she looks back at how the past two and a half years have shifted her thinking on technology.
item.dc:creator: Shira Ovide

item.title: With Drought, ‘Spanish Stonehenge’ Emerges Once Again
item.description: The Dolmen of Guadalperal, a Bronze Age stone monument newly exposed by plummeting water levels in Europe, is now imperiled by tourists.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.media:description: The Dolmen of Guadalperal, a megalithic archaeological site exposed by drought at the Valdecañas reservoir in western Spain.

item.title: How Silicon Chips Rule the World
item.description: Maintaining the flow of oil is still crucial for the world economy. But now the supply of semiconductors is also critical for commerce, and war and peace.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:description: Two chips on display at the Taiwan Semiconductor Research Institute in Hsinchu. Taiwan is a colossus in the global market for semiconductors, the brains of modern electronics.

item.title: After Long Brawl, South Carolina Senate Approves More Abortion Restrictions
item.description: Legislators failed to advance a total ban on abortion, instead adding more restrictions to an existing law. The G.O.P. split over exceptions for rape and incest.
item.dc:creator: Ava Sasani
item.media:description: Protesters gathered inside the South Carolina House on Tuesday, as members debated a new near-total ban on abortion.

item.title: I.R.S. to Refund Late-Filing Penalties for 2019 and 2020 Returns
item.description: But to be eligible for the relief, taxpayers have to file the returns by Sept. 30. The agency says the average refund will be $750.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: What Is Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma? Jane Fonda’s Cancer Diagnosis
item.description: Jane Fonda recently revealed that she was diagnosed with the cancer. Doctors explained the symptoms, testing and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Can You Have Alcohol After the Covid Vaccine and Booster Shot?
item.description: Moderate drinking is unlikely to impair the immune response to the Covid vaccine, but heavy drinking might.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor

item.title: How to Prevent Memory Loss
item.description: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
item.dc:creator: Hope Reese
item.category: The Complete Guide to Memory: The Science of Strengthening Your Mind (Book)

item.title: What Are Neti Pots and How Do They Work?
item.description: Nasal rinsing has been used for thousands of years to relieve sinus inflammation, congestion, allergy symptoms and more. Here’s what the evidence says.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan

item.title: How to Handle Returning to the Office
item.description: The gossip, the loud talker and the nosy colleague are all manageable with the right mind-set.
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: How One Couple Uprooted Their Life to Open an Inn in the Catskills
item.description: In early 2020, Maureen McNamara and her wife, Jennifer Stark, traded in their popular restaurant in Michigan for an inn nestled in the Catskill Mountains of New York. The inn opened just days before the pandemic was declared.
item.dc:creator: Alix Strauss
item.media:credit: Jasmine Clarke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Stark, left, and Maureen McNamara took a leap of faith and opened the Phoenicia Lodge in the Catskill Mountains of New York in early 2020.
